body.p:
All together 24 to whom I have already delivered it. Since then the
following men have moved from here: David Dinkelspiel to California,
H. Stern, to Ohio, L. Silverman to Indiana. I still have to deliver to
the following: M. Godshaw, who is noe in New York on a buying trip, M. A.
Kohn, in New Albany, and B. Sachs, who denies from beginning to end that
he ever subscribed. I shall still find the opportunity to send them to
Stern and Silverman.

I was in Albany and they have no money there. Most of them
promised to pay towards the end of July and August, when their heavy bus-
iness payments will have been attended to. I cannot possibly go the same
man three or four times for I feel that he might develop a bad opinion of
me. One would not have thought that such a small matter would make any
difference to people but when I tell you that Emanuel Bamberger, a man
with a capital of $50,000, refused to pay me for that reason, less
wealthy men are not to be surprised at. Aside from that many, like Lich-

body.p:
ten, Sol Hart, Bach, Godshaw, Ullman, etc., are not even here. Herewith
you receive all that I have. Add to that $9.75 which I spent for you.
The check cost me 60 cents.

I have not sold a single copy of Dias down to the present
time. Of prayer books, I haven't received any and those that I requested,
you need not send until about Rosh Hashonnah. The bill which you sent me
in your letter of — cannot possibly be correct. Have the goodness to
look through the records again, and all the letters which I sent you since
1850. Note these and let me know. After that I shall try to adjust all
that is missing. In your subscription lists for the “Occident” there is
such a confusion that I am quite unable to make anything of it. When I
canvass, no one outside of your older subscribers wants to hear anything
about it, or owe anything for it. when you realize your decision again
to make a trip to the west, it will probably be advantageous for you in
every respect. You have not answered my last letter, in which I asked
you to suggest a subject for our school which is about to be built. Per-
haps this was due to your waiting for the letter I promised you, but I
could not write it for the reason that uncertainty continued
to hang over the entire project. It may still fail. We have elected an
English teacher, whose duties are to commence at the first of September,
at a salary of $600. a year, but the projected schoolhouse has not yet
been begun. In a very short time I shall be able to inform you how
things are going in this respect. I hope to God that the plan will not
fail. And now, my dear Mr. Leeser, I want to tell you something about
my private affairs. Since the appearance of the last “Occident”, I have
received letters from San Francisco, not officially, but from several f
friends who advise me to try to get the position there. What do you
think about it? Will you advise me to do so, and will you also perhaps
help me? These are the best years of my life. I have a good position
6-20-1854

here and perhaps even a secure one. But to this day I am still as poor
as 5 years ago and every year I have to depend upon the uncertain favor
of every ass. Perhaps I ought to be careful and not seek after that po-
sition. Perhaps you can let me know the exact conditions and tell me f
frankly whether you consider me sufficiently fitted or not and whether you
will recommend me for it. Since my stay here I have had unusual practice
in the matter of preaching and without being immodest I think I can say
that I perfected myself in it. I feel that I can fill that position.
Please write to me about it as soon as possible.

Dr. Wise was here. His books are practically all lying around here.
His subscribers do not want to take them up. Personally and in writing,
he asked me to do something about it, but I explained to him unhesitating-
ly that it was contrary to my principles to further in any respect a work
so destructive of Judaism.
Write by return post to your servant and friend,

This afternoon, a contract was signed for a schoolhouse. It
cost $3300. and is to be built upon the community's property, behind the
synagogue, 45 feet front and 60 feet deep, 4 small rooms below and a large
hall above, occupying the entire space.
6-20-1854
